data.title: Writing Adolescent Fiction/Character names/Portuguese
data.text:
Brazil is a melting pot of immigration, and although your Brazilians will have Portuguese first names, there are also Brazilians with last names like Weber, Anderson, McCall, Sacco, Levitt, Gómez and Watanabe, especially of Anglo-Saxon influence (Smith, Gardner, Taylor, Jordan, Wheeler, etc.), or even based in popular international stars. The majority of Brazilians have Portuguese last names, like Pereira, Márques, Fagundes, Costa, Dos Santos, and others. A very common practice is the combination of two first names (María Daniela, Ana Beatriz, Paulo Henrique, José Elias) and then the surnames. Italian and German names also had a great impact during the second world war and the period after when waves of immigration reached South America.

Names in Portugal, not unlike those used in Brazil are also hugely influenced by the past, but have stricter legal requirements on registry. You will find that non-Portuguese names are rare, but not uncommon, you may have also Anglo-Saxon names but rarely as the first name and surnames have a deeper hereditary relation with the family tree. Some influences may be found in Portuguese names that are rarer (in proportion in Brazil), like Spanish and French surnames. Note that Portugal was invaded by the French during the Napoleonic wars and England had a great impact in the north of the country, this is specially observable in the control of Porto wine production and export. Diminutives like Teresinha (from Teresa) are not found in names in Portugal, but have an acceptable use to express endearment or as a reference to the age of the subject (Teresinha means little Teresa).

African names are extremely rare in Brazil and Portugal but common in countries that still retain native dialects, like Angola or Mozambique mixed with Portuguese names. Like in Brazil there is also a greater impact in media in regard to the selection of names, in Africa names tend to come mostly from famous football players.

In other nations that had a Portuguese influence or still speak Portuguese the local names are mixed with local ones, for instance Portuguese names are still used in Goa, Philippines and Macao.
